p: FRAPPE and ADMIXTURE are based on a similar approach to STRUCTURE, but both use a maximum likelihood estimation approach to optimise the likelihood for allele frequencies and group memberships, using slightly different algorithms. By default, ADMIXTURE uses a block relaxation algorithm that allows for fast convergence and highly accurate parameter estimates [ 143] and has an optional Expectation-Maximisation (EM) algorithm. FRAPPE uses solely the EM algorithm [ 144], which optimises the likelihood for both allele frequencies and fractional group memberships [ 144]. FRAPPE has been demonstrated to not only be much more computationally efficient than STRUCTURE but also to produce significantly fewer biased estimates [ 144]. However, due to its strict convergence criteria, its EM algorithm is computationally intensive and slower than ADMIXTURE [ 143], which was reported to have higher accuracy than STRUCTURE and FRAPPE.
